G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, and 31A, and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31, and 31.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, and 31A, and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, and 31A, and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction to modify custody and parenting time under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 208, § 31, as the original judgment was issued by this Court and the child has resided in Massachusetts at all relevant times.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction to modify custody and parenting time under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 208, § 31, as the original judgment was issued by this Court and the child has resided in Massachusetts at all relevant times.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue in the Norfolk Probate and Family Court is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 6 and G.L. c. 215, § 3, because the original judgment entered in this Court and the parties and minor child reside within its jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6 to fashion orders necessary to protect the best interests of the minor child and to ensure her safety, stability, and welfare.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the minor child’s welfare, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law, including but not limited to Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 822 (1999).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn concerns the need for explicit findings on the effects of domestic violence when making an initial custody determination and interpreting G.L. c. 208, § 31, not § 28. It does not discuss the standard for modifying an existing custody order, nor does it articulate or apply the ‘substantial and material change in circumstances’ requirement that governs post‑judgment modification under § 28. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition that there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances since a prior order.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking. The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f… the court orders shared legal or physical custody… the court shall provide written findings….’”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the minor child’s welfare, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law, including but not limited to Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 822 (1999).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas concerns standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the “real advantage” test when a custodial parent seeks to relocate. It does not address the threshold requirement for modification of an existing custody order based on a “substantial and material change in circumstances” under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Thus, while it is relevant to relocation and best‑interests analysis, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about a material change since a prior order.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 822 (1999).proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Order, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the minor child’s welfare, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law, including but not limited to Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 822 (1999).
Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 822 (1999).case_name: Medical Professional Mutual Insurance v. Breon Laboratories, Inc.
Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 822 (1999).support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 822 (1999), but a contribution‑among‑joint‑tortfeasors case interpreting G.L. c. 231B § 3 and the meaning of “judgment.” It does not concern custody, removal, or any standard for “substantial and material change in circumstances” under G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it address the child‑welfare considerations cited in the proposition. Accordingly, this opinion does not support the claimed proposition about post‑judgment changes affecting a minor child’s welfare.
Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 822 (1999).relevant_excerpt: The question certified, which concerns the applicability of certain sections of G. L. c. 231B, the contribution among joint tortfeasors act, is as follows: “Does the term ‘judgment,’ appearing in sections 3(c) and (d) of Mass. Gen. Laws Ann. ch. 231B (the Contribution Among Joint Tortfeasors Act), encompass a judgment entered upon a general verdict, pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 58(a), even though the litigation subsequently is settled pursuant to an agreement between the parties?” … For the following reasons we answer the question, “Yes.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the Massachusetts standard for modifying custody orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and it tracks the two-part test in the proposition: a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. The court then applies that standard to evaluate the modification of legal custody, confirming it as the governing rule.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the substantive standard for determining custody—i.e., that the welfare or best interests of the child is the governing principle and that all relevant factors must be weighed. It does not address when or under what standard an existing custody or parenting time order may be modified, nor does it articulate a requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances for modification. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The onset and progression of a serious medical condition that affects a parent’s ability to safely care for a child has been recognized under Massachusetts law as a legitimate basis to revisit custody and parenting time in order to serve the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is a general custody dispute between unmarried parents focusing on the ‘best interests of the child’ and statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). It does not involve, discuss, or recognize the onset or progression of any serious medical condition affecting a parent’s ability to care for a child as a basis to revisit custody or parenting time. The only medical references concern the child’s medical needs, not a parent’s health condition, so the case does not support the specific medical-change-based modification proposition stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Ultimately, the judge concluded that the mother was more ‘attuned to [Kali’s] medical, educational, and daily needs’ and this tipped the balance as to where the best interests of the child lay.” (439 Mass. at 847-848).

Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).proposition: The onset and progression of a serious medical condition that affects a parent’s ability to safely care for a child has been recognized under Massachusetts law as a legitimate basis to revisit custody and parenting time in order to serve the child’s best interests.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a care-and-protection proceeding based on psychological conflict, the child’s strong preference, and the mother’s refusal to address those issues—not the onset or progression of any serious medical condition affecting a parent’s caregiving ability. There is no discussion of parental illness or medical decline as a basis to revisit custody or parenting time. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific medical-condition-based proposition stated.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “A finding of parental unfitness may be predicated on the circumstances within a particular family, as they adversely affect the particular child, without regard to the general quality of parental conduct per se. ‘It is not the quality or character of parental conduct per se that justifies State intervention on behalf of an abused, neglected, or otherwise endangered child. Rather, it is the fact of the endangerment itself.’… The State may constitutionally deprive otherwise fit parents of custody… upon a persuasive showing that return of that custody to the parents would create a substantial risk or likelihood of serious harm to the child.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has repeatedly held that the “best interests of the child” are the overriding consideration in all custody determinations, and that the Court must consider the child’s welfare in light of current circumstances, not merely those existing at the time of the original judgment.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly applies the "best interests of the child" standard as the central and overriding consideration in this custody/adoption dispute, which supports that portion of the proposition. However, the cited pages do not state that the court must consider the child’s welfare specifically "in light of current circumstances, not merely those existing at the time of the original judgment," nor do they discuss revisiting or modifying an earlier custody judgment on the basis of changed circumstances. The case is about choosing between two placement plans at the time of decision, not about temporal comparison to an earlier judgment, so it does not support the second part of the proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’"

Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007)
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has repeatedly held that the “best interests of the child” are the overriding consideration in all custody determinations, and that the Court must consider the child’s welfare in light of current circumstances, not merely those existing at the time of the original judgment.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that the child’s best interests are the ‘touchstone’ and must be considered in light of the child’s current circumstances, including existing bonds with caregivers. However, it does not state that the Supreme Judicial Court has ‘repeatedly held’ that best interests are the overriding consideration in all custody determinations; rather, it emphasizes that parental unfitness is the critical inquiry when the State seeks to interfere with parental custody. The case thus discusses the interaction between unfitness and best interests, but does not adopt the broad proposition attributed to the SJC.
Guardianship of Estelle, 70 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘critical inquiry’ in such cases is finding parental unfitness by clear and convincing evidence… At the same time, the ‘best interests of the child’ is the touchstone of the analysis… The question, then, is how to balance a parent’s capacity to care adequately for a child (i.e., his or her ‘fitness’) with that child’s ‘best interests,’ given the child’s current circumstances.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 540\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts case law, modification of custody and parenting orders requires a demonstration of “a material and substantial change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment” and that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 540\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on relocation and the paternity statute, not on the standard for modification of existing custody and parenting orders. It does not articulate or apply the familiar Massachusetts modification test requiring a material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests of the child. Because the opinion segment neither discusses modification standards nor uses that formulation, it does not support the claimed proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 540\u2.relevant_excerpt:
I concur that the judgment must be vacated and the case remanded to the Probate and Family Court for further proceedings as to custody and visitation in light of the “special exception” set out by the court. Ante at 555.

The paternity statute further provides that “the mother shall continue to have custody after an adjudication of paternity or voluntary acknowledgment of parentage” (emphasis added) unless and until a court orders otherwise. G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (b).
